When I was 12, I used Apple II GS at school and a Tandy 1000 TX. The Tandy 
had 16 colors @ 640X200 res and 3-voice fm synthesis sound, 640K main ram 
with 128K extended ram, a 40 meg hd card, one 5 1/4 and one 3 1/2 floppy 
drives. It ran with MSDOS 3.2. A few years later a 2 meg expanded ram card, 
a vga card, and adlib sound card was added to play more games. Those were 
the simple good times.﻿

graphics. Of course these features and capabilities came later during the 
late 80's.

comments.text:
The less overhead a child has to learn for an activity means the more brain 
space they have for other things. Instead of having to remember 
command-line BS and floppy this and reset that, all they have to do is 
focus on their goal (eg: writing a term paper, or researching something on 
the internet).

The reason there is a life cycle is so old farts like you and I get removed 
from society instead of living forever and trying to force old, archaic 
ways of doing things upon the next generation. Think of all the crap they 
didn't have to learn... that brain space can be used for many more useful 
things (but is most likely taken up by playing video games and looking at 
porn ... hey, our generation did it, too, we just had to work harder at 
it). Just because our generation had to work harder at something doesn't 
mean it was better. It just means it was bloated and overly-convoluted. 
Each generation streamlines things that the prior generation invented and 
bloated up. It's the cycle of life.

or GPU-intensive game. Of course modern laptop systems will blow a 
Commodore out of the water, but a Commodore seems a much better system to

fast a processor is. It only leads to confusion. Example: an Intel Pentium 
G3420 (3.2GHz, dual-core) processor can out-perform an AMD Athlon II X2 250 
(Overclocked at 3.6GHz). Back when the Commodore was about, clock speed 
mattered, but not any more.

+VisioningHail , yep the internet was certainly available to people in 
1992. I was starting college around this time, where all students were 
given a login to the school's system along with an email account and some 
quota of space.  But commercially speaking, yes, people could get their own 
internet accounts by signing up with an ISP (Internet Service Provider) 
like AOL, Prodigy, or Compuserve. They'd typically give you a floppy disc 
which let you set up your account, had internet tools you could use, etc.  
Tons more ISPs became available as the popularity of the internet grew, and 
I managed to steer clear of AOL and go with one of the cheaper providers 
for home.

comments.text:
Don't forget about the Laser 128 which was an Apple II clone. I saw those 
on eBay recently. I loved my Apple IIgs, but Apple //e was nice too. First 
PC was the TRS-80 Model III with cassette. I also had a Z80 card on my //e 
which allowed it to use CPM. (I had a CPM-based word processor.) I also had 
the PC Transporter (PC clone on a card) on my IIgs. I also learned alot 
while using the various versions of DOS for PCs. I know keystrokes from 
Windows 3.x that are still part of Windows 8. Most people need an app to do 
a screen capture when Alt-PrintScreen and Ctrl-PrintScreen can do the same. 
After using that keystroke, go to a program like Paint and hit paste. With 
WIndows 7, Paint became a decent program. (Not sure about Vista, never used 
it.)

I agree kids need to learn and experience where we came from. Modern kids 
sound lazy as well as some adults. If your computer crashes or internet 
service goes down, what would you do? Go to the library and learn to look 
things up without Google or Bing. Do a rough draft of a paper by hand. 
Learn to take notes.

After I noticed the laziness, even The Jetsons started annoying me. 
Everyone panics because a button doesn't work. Well, learn to cook with a 
stove. At least learn to cook some canned soup.

Windows 2000 and Windows ME -> Windows XP -> Windows Vista -> Windows 7 ->

comments.text:
I am fortunate that I live in a major city where there is a well stocked 
library in every neighborhood. Aside from books every community uses them 
as gathering places, classrooms, and community centers. Aside from books 
they offer brightly lit and comfortable places to sit, write and use 
computers. Seniors use them to relax and read periodicals and check out 
cookbooks. Kids go there after school for activities. The homeless go there 
to receive services, look for housing and work and just sit. Classes and 
seminars are held there. Art galleries debut there. The great thing is that 
they are up to times, so you can reserve and even request orders through 
the internet on a PC, tablet, or phone. You can also "borrow" ebooks too. 
(And those ebooks are easily cracked through some simple third party 
software through like Calibre, so you can keep the, forever.)

I previously lived in a small town (that was geographically pretty big) 
where there was only one library where I would have to ride a car for 20 
minutes just to get to. It was a nice library but not one I could go to 
daily. The one in my neighborhood now is always on my way home, and I go 
there every other day.

glad to go to a library if it's inside about a mile's walking distance.

Closest library to here is about seven miles...no bloody way, sorry books I 
love ya but that would kill me.
I'm still happy to buy books online at least on occasion or on trips.

captions.text:
- (Finebros) Today you are reacting to this!
- What is this?
It looks cool! I like pressing buttons.
If you don't a desk, where do you put this?

What do you think of it
just from looking at it?

Kinda like those old televisions 
that are very boxy.

(Finebros) So you turn the monitor on,
where else might an on switch be?

- (Finebros) It's in the back.
- Oh, pfff.
Oh! I see where it is.
Why does it have to make so much noise?
And there's nothing on the screen.

Doesn't look anything like
what we have now.
But THIS thing right here has nothing!

(Finebros) Go ahead and try to do 
something on the computer.

(Finebros) You can't do anything 
or even type until you hit

- a reset button that's on the computer--
- Ugggggh!
It's like pre-flight checks kind of.

(Finebros) Everything is just 
done with the keyboard.

- (Finebros) Okay, now--
- Nah, no, no, no.
Wait, it doesn't matter. Blah blah blah.
Are there any programs on it?

(Finebros) You had to type into 
the keyboard to get it to do anything.
So if I type in GAMES...
(Finebros) How do you go on the internet?

Pretty sure Timothy Berners Lee
didn't create it yet.
(Finebros) There was no internet back then!
Then how do you look up homework?
(Finebros) You gotta go to the library!

(Finebros) So computers back then
could only do limited things.

For example, you can do math, 
type documents and code...

- but that's about it.
- Are you serious?
That was the peak of technology.

Well, it's kinda good because it 
was kinda the first technology, but...
computers today are kind of better.

(Finebros) Let's do some math.
Go ahead, type in a math problem.

(Finebros) When you just type numbers out,
the computer doesn't know

what you want it do.
It just sees the numbers.

You need to give it 
a command to let it know,
"Hey! I'm about to give you numbers!"

You have to give some sort of command 
and then type in what you want it to do?

This would be the hardest 
thing in the world!

(Finebros) So what you need to do
is you have to type the world PRINT first.
Math has nothing to do with PRINT!

I don't get how you have to put PRINT
when nothing prints out.
I feel so proud of myself.
And I also don't get the 1970s.

The person that was using this
a long time ago
must have a lot of codes right next to them.
I don't want to do this anymore!

(Finebros) So besides the computer,
there is something else next to it.

(Finebros) Do you have any idea
what those things are?

- (Finebros) They're actually used for this.
- Hey!
It was like a flash drive.

(Finebros) They actually call 
that a floppy disk.

(Finebros) That big computer 
has no hard drive on it.
Then why is it so big?

(Finebros) So floppy disks 
were used to store data.

Floppy disks could also come 
with programs on them.

So the one you're holding
has a version of DOS.

- (Finebros) You know what DOS is?
- No.

I think it it can be 
somebody's last name.

(Finebros) Do you want to play 
a game on the computer?
Could you grab the floppy disk, please?
How do I put this in?
(Finebros) Oh, it might...is the lid shut?

(Finebros) Alright, turn it around.
No, other way. Now turn it around.
I don't like this computer. Really don't.

(Finebros) If the computer was 
already on and you put in the disk,

you gotta turn the computer 
off and turn it back on.
No, no, no! Don't touch it.
Do I have to pay for it?
It's green, which makes it look ugly.
I like this better than Flappy Bird!

(Finebros) So every computer, even today,
has something called a processor

inside of it and depending on how good
your processor is is how powerful

You would need at least 850 
of those computers to equal

- the single power of this one small phone.
- What?

Look at how humanity 
has used their intellect.

(Finebros) So, finally, would you
want one of these today?
No. It can do really nothing.

I have better things,
so why would I want this?

Three decades ago I 
would love to have this,
but now this is just a foot stool.
No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no!

The games are boring, 
the stuff is boring
and the whole thing is boring.

Thanks for watching this 
technological episode of Kids React!

Leave a comment of which technology 
we should react to next.
